member.name: T:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevel
member.summary: Defines the compatibility level / conventions to use when encoding common types into protobuf. When starting a new green-field project the highest available level can be safely applied, but note that changing the compatibility level changes the encoding. For this reason, it should not be casually changed on brown-field projects, unless you are also knowingly breaking the encoding requirements of pre-existing data. If not specified, the oldest (lowest number) is assumed, for safety.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevel.NotSpecified
member.summary: Functionally identical to

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevel.Level200
member.summary: Uses bcl.proto for , , and , for compatibility with all versions of protobuf-net, at the expense of being inconvenient for use with other protobuf implementations.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevel.Level240
member.summary: Like , but uses '.google.protobuf.Timestamp' for and '.google.protobuf.Duration' for . This is functionally identical to a configuration that specifies .

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevel.Level300
member.summary: Like , but uses 'string' for (big-endian hyphenated UUID format; a shorter 'bytes' variant is also available via ) and (invariant "general" format).

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevelAttribute
member.summary: Defines the compatibiltiy level to use for an element

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevelAttribute.Level
member.summary: The compatibiltiy level to use for this element

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevelAttribute.#ctor(ProtoBuf.CompatibilityLevel)
member.summary: Create a new CompatibilityLevelAttribute instance

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.DataFormat
member.summary: Sub-format to use when serializing/deserializing data

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.DataFormat.Default
member.summary: Uses the default encoding for the data-type.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.DataFormat.ZigZag
member.summary: When applied to signed integer-based data (including Decimal), this indicates that zigzag variant encoding will be used. This means that values with small magnitude (regardless of sign) take a small amount of space to encode.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.DataFormat.TwosComplement
member.summary: When applied to signed integer-based data (including Decimal), this indicates that two's-complement variant encoding will be used. This means that any -ve number will take 10 bytes (even for 32-bit), so should only be used for compatibility.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.DataFormat.FixedSize
member.summary: When applied to signed integer-based data (including Decimal), this indicates that a fixed amount of space will be used.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.DataFormat.Group
member.summary: When applied to a sub-message, indicates that the value should be treated as group-delimited.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.DataFormat.WellKnown
member.summary: When applied to members of types such as DateTime or TimeSpan, specifies that the "well known" standardized representation should be use; DateTime uses Timestamp, TimeSpan uses Duration.

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.Extensible
member.summary: Simple base class for supporting unexpected fields allowing for loss-less round-tips/merge, even if the data is not understod. The additional fields are (by default) stored in-memory in a buffer.
member.remarks: As an example of an alternative implementation, you might choose to use the file system (temporary files) as the back-end, tracking only the paths [such an object would ideally be IDisposable and use a finalizer to ensure that the files are removed].

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.Extensible.GetExtensionObject(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieves the extension object for the current instance, optionally creating it if it does not already exist.
member.param: Should a new extension object be created if it does not already exist?
member.returns: The extension object if it exists (or was created), or null if the extension object does not exist or is not available.
member.remarks: The createIfMissing argument is false during serialization, and true during deserialization upon encountering unexpected fields.

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.Extensible.GetExtensionObject(ProtoBuf.IExtension@,System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Provides a simple, default implementation for extension support, optionally creating it if it does not already exist. Designed to be called by classes implementing .
member.param: Should a new extension object be created if it does not already exist?
The that holds the fields, in terms of the inheritance model; the same tag key can appear against different type levels for the same instance, with different values.
The extension field to check (and possibly update).
member.returns: The extension object if it exists (or was created), or null if the extension object does not exist or is not available.
member.remarks: The createIfMissing argument is false during serialization, and true during deserialization upon encountering unexpected fields.

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.Extensible.GetExtensionObject(ProtoBuf.IExtension@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Provides a simple, default implementation for extension support, optionally creating it if it does not already exist. Designed to be called by classes implementing .

True if the append operation completed successfully.

member.summary: Requests a stream of the unexpected fields previously stored.
member.returns: A prepared stream of the unexpected fields.

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.IExtension.EndQuery(System.IO.Stream)

member.param: The stream originally obtained by BeginQuery.

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.ImplicitFields
member.summary: Specifies the method used to infer field tags for members of the type under consideration. Tags are deduced using the invariant alphabetic sequence of the members' names; this makes implicit field tags very brittle, and susceptible to changes such as field names (normally an isolated change).

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.ImplicitFields.None
member.summary: No members are serialized implicitly; all members require a suitable attribute such as [ProtoMember]. This is the recmomended mode for most scenarios.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.ImplicitFields.AllPublic
member.summary: Public properties and fields are eligible for implicit serialization; this treats the public API as a contract. Ordering beings from ImplicitFirstTag.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.ImplicitFields.AllFields
member.summary: Public and non-public fields are eligible for implicit serialization; this acts as a state/implementation serializer. Ordering beings from ImplicitFirstTag.

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.Meta.TypeModel.DeserializeItems(System.IO.Stream,System.Type,ProtoBuf.PrefixStyle,System.Int32,ProtoBuf.TypeResolver)
member.summary: Reads a sequence of consecutive length-prefixed items from a stream, using either base-128 or fixed-length prefixes. Base-128 prefixes with a tag are directly comparable to serializing multiple items in succession (use the tag to emulate the implicit behavior when serializing a list/array). When a tag is specified, any records with different tags are silently omitted. The tag is ignored. The tag is ignores for fixed-length prefixes.
member.param: The binary stream containing the serialized records.
The prefix style used in the data.
The tag of records to return (if non-positive, then no tag is expected and all records are returned).
On a field-by-field basis, the type of object to deserialize (can be null if "type" is specified).
The type of object to deserialize (can be null if "resolver" is specified).
member.returns: The sequence of deserialized objects.

summary.para: This is the more "complete" version of Deserialize, which handles single instances of mapped types. The value is read as a complete field, including field-header and (for sub-objects) a length-prefix..kmc
In addition to that, this provides support for: - basic values; individual int / string / Guid / etc - IList sets of any type handled by TryDeserializeAuxiliaryType

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.Meta.TypeModel.ListItemTag
member.summary: The field number that is used as a default when serializing/deserializing a list of objects. The data is treated as repeated message with field number 1.

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.PrefixStyle
member.summary: Specifies the type of prefix that should be applied to messages.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.PrefixStyle.None
member.summary: No length prefix is applied to the data; the data is terminated only be the end of the stream.

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.PrefixStyle.Base128
member.summary: A base-128 ("varint", the default prefix format in protobuf) length prefix is applied to the data (efficient for short messages).

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.PrefixStyle.Fixed32
member.summary: A fixed-length (little-endian) length prefix is applied to the data (useful for compatibility).

member.name: F:ProtoBuf.PrefixStyle.Fixed32BigEndian
member.summary: A fixed-length (big-endian) length prefix is applied to the data (useful for compatibility).

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a type is defined for protocol-buffer serialization.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the defined name of the type. This can be fully qualified , for example .foo.bar.someType if required.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.Origin
member.summary: Gets or sets the file that defines this type (as used with import in .proto)

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.ImplicitFirstTag
member.summary: Gets or sets the fist offset to use with implicit field tags; only uesd if ImplicitFields is set.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.UseProtoMembersOnly
member.summary: If specified, alternative contract markers (such as markers for XmlSerailizer or DataContractSerializer) are ignored.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.IgnoreListHandling
member.summary: If specified, do NOT treat this type as a list, even if it looks like one.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.ImplicitFields
member.summary: Gets or sets the mechanism used to automatically infer field tags for members. This option should be used in advanced scenarios only. Please review the important notes against the ImplicitFields enumeration.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.InferTagFromName
member.summary: Enables/disables automatic tag generation based on the existing name / order of the defined members. This option is not used for members marked with ProtoMemberAttribute, as intended to provide compatibility with WCF serialization. WARNING: when adding new fields you must take care to increase the Order for new elements, otherwise data corruption may occur.
member.remarks: If not explicitly specified, the default is assumed from Serializer.GlobalOptions.InferTagFromName.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.InferTagFromNameHasValue
member.summary: Has a InferTagFromName value been explicitly set? if not, the default from the type-model is assumed.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.DataMemberOffset
member.summary:
Specifies an offset to apply to [DataMember(Order=...)] markers; this is useful when working with mex-generated classes that have a different origin (usually 1 vs 0) than the original data-contract.
This value is added to the Order of each member.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.SkipConstructor
member.summary: If true, the constructor for the type is bypassed during deserialization, meaning any field initializers or other initialization code is skipped.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.AsReferenceDefault
member.summary: Should this type be treated as a reference by default? Please also see the implications of this, as recorded on ProtoMemberAttribute.AsReference

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.IsGroup
member.summary: Indicates whether this type should always be treated as a "group" (rather than a string-prefixed sub-message)

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.IgnoreUnknownSubTypes
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether unknown sub-types should cause serialization failure

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.EnumPassthru
member.summary: Applies only to enums (not to DTO classes themselves); gets or sets a value indicating that an enum should be treated directly as an int/short/etc, rather than enforcing .proto enum rules. This is useful *in particul* for [Flags] enums.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.Surrogate
member.summary: Defines a surrogate type used for serialization/deserialization purpose.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoContractAttribute.Serializer
member.summary: Defines a serializer to use for this type; the serializer must implement ISerializer-T for this type

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.ProtoConverterAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a static member should be considered the same as though were an implicit / explicit conversion operator; in particular, this is useful for conversions that operator syntax does not allow, such as to/from interface types.

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.ProtoEnumAttribute
member.summary: Used to define protocol-buffer specific behavior for enumerated values.

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoEnumAttribute.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the specific value to use for this enum during serialization.

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.ProtoEnumAttribute.HasValue
member.summary: Indicates whether this instance has a customised value mapping
member.returns: true if a specific value is set

member.name: P:ProtoBuf.ProtoEnumAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the defined name of the enum, as used in .proto (this name is not used during serialization).

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.TypedExtensible.GetValues``1(ProtoBuf.ITypedExtensible,System.Int32,System.Type,ProtoBuf.DataFormat,ProtoBuf.Meta.TypeModel)
member.summary: Queries an extensible object for an additional (unexpected) data-field for the instance. Each occurrence of the field is yielded separately, making this usage suitable for "repeated" (list) fields.
member.remarks: The extended data is processed lazily as the enumerator is iterated.

member.returns: An enumerator that yields each occurrence of the field.

member.name: M:ProtoBuf.TypedExtensible.AppendValue``1(ProtoBuf.ITypedExtensible,System.Int32,``0,System.Type,ProtoBuf.DataFormat,ProtoBuf.Meta.TypeModel)
member.summary: Appends the value as an additional (unexpected) data-field for the instance. Note that for non-repeated sub-objects, this equates to a merge operation; for repeated sub-objects this adds a new instance to the set; for simple values the new value supercedes the old value.
member.remarks: Note that appending a value does not remove the old value from the stream; avoid repeatedly appending values for the same field.
member.param: The data-format to use when encoding the value.
The model to use for serialization.
The extensible object to append the value to.
The field identifier; the tag should not be defined as a known data-field for the instance.

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.WellKnownTypes.Duration
member.summary: A Duration represents a signed, fixed-length span of time represented as a count of seconds and fractions of seconds at nanosecond resolution. It is independent of any calendar and concepts like "day" or "month". It is related to Timestamp in that the difference between two Timestamp values is a Duration and it can be added or subtracted from a Timestamp.

member.name: T:ProtoBuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp
member.summary: A Timestamp represents a point in time independent of any time zone or local calendar, encoded as a count of seconds and fractions of seconds at nanosecond resolution. The count is relative to an epoch at UTC midnight on January 1, 1970, in the proleptic Gregorian calendar which extends the Gregorian calendar backwards to year one.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that certain members on a specified are accessed dynamically, for example through .
member.remarks:
This allows tools to understand which members are being accessed during the execution of a program.
This attribute is valid on members whose type is or .
When this attribute is applied to a location of type , the assumption is that the string represents a fully qualified type name.
If the attribute is applied to a method it's treated as a special case and it implies the attribute should be applied to the "this" parameter of the method. As such the attribute should only be used on instance methods of types assignable to System.Type (or string, but no methods will use it there).
